data.text: What Is the Availability of Camping Gas Stoves in India?

Hi fellow long distance friends ðŸ‘‹ a quick question if anyone has spent some time touring in India...what is the availability of camping gas canisters like? ðŸ¤” The screw in or EZ click type specifically I'm planning a tour and thinking about kit, I really don't want to have to bring a petrol stove if I can help it but I know deep down that that's the most practical option. If its reasonably easy to get ahold of the gas, for example in supermarkets in big cities or something, then I would feel justified in my decision to bring my gas stove rather than a petrol stove ðŸ˜„ I have been informed on a post in a different cycling group that one could order them off Amazon.in, but im curious about accessibility from just regular shops rather than online! I know I won't be cooking and using my stove as frequently as perhaps I do on other trips because of roadside eateries for example in India...I do like to self cater on tour where possible or at least have the option easily, due to allergies though ðŸ˜Š
Following.
data.author: Michael Bryant

data.text: Maybe google camping stores and see whats available? I'm usually allright with one cylinder per month but like to have the possibility to cook. Having said that, there is a lot of good food around in India and no actual need to cook.
data.author: Karl Mellacher

data.text: good idea! I tried this but a lot of them don't have up to date websites ðŸ˜‚ I could possibly email a camping store though...ðŸ¤”
data.author: Sophia Attwood

data.text: Same story, very little need to cook because of all the street stalls.. on the other hand ,I don't remember gas canisters being easy to find :/ Maybe has more to say on the topic?
data.author: Katrien Kat Spelkens

data.text: I'm mainly thinking I might need my stove for coffee (not much coffee about at roadside stalls so I hear) and also for the possibility of self catering because I'm allergic to nuts...I guess different regions might use nuts in certain dishes and I might need to be careful! ðŸ¤” I won't know until I arrive for sure what the situation is because most people are saying to me the same thing about not needing to cook much! ðŸ˜‚
data.author: Sophia Attwood

data.text: unless you're happy with instant coffee, nope.. not much of a coffee culture by the road. In the south they do have great coffee though! The nuts might be troublesome.. I can imagine it won't be easy to ask/explain in roadside dhabbas :) either way, it's good to have the option to self cater indeed!
data.author: Katrien Kat Spelkens

data.text: I'm afraid finding canisters might be a bit of a quest indeed.. there's decathlon in some of the bigger cities and they usually have some, and I'm sure you might find some in other places but it won't always be easy.. of course if you stick to using it just for the coffee, one canister can go a long wayðŸ˜‰ (and then again you might discover that chai is really the way to go!ðŸ˜›) I understand you wanting to be able to cater for yourself, but I found myself cooking on a wood/hobo stove most of the timeðŸ™‚ I wouldn't worry about nuts too much, in most of the common dishes in the north you won't find them (beware of sweets though!), in the south there might be coconut in some dishes.. good luck and have fun! ðŸ˜‰
data.author: Jef Ghysens

data.text: Ahh, I echo the sentiment, India street food and restaurants is enough. We cycled 5 months Kochi to Nepal...and I can't remember when we used our gas stove....it's more of a comfort factor that you are "self contained"....
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: , even Shimla to Leh, you didn't use a stove?
data.author: Joe Sealby

data.text: That was another month after Nepal, and yes then we did, but really not that much either.
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: , we're thinking of having a go at that ride next year and just curious to make our panniers as light as possible.
data.author: Joe Sealby

data.text:
Excellent! Our only problem was in Batal, May 29 and the road just opened, we were the first cyclists through. And we camped then and used the stove of course. But really we usually could find a guest house with a restaurant or these parachute camps. https://www.cycleblaze.com/journals/racpatrtw/to-batal-3900m-over-kunzum-la-4590m/
to Batal - 3900m: over Kunzum La (4590m) - Racpat RTW 2015-2017 - CycleBlaze
cycleblaze.com
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: x Wow. It looks like a lot has happened since your trip in 2016. Joe - I am mostly writing this to you, if you want some newer info on northern India. First of all the prices has gone up. A lot. For a simple room for a night, you will pay 900rupees and upwards. The most we payed was 3500 including breakfast and dinner. A lot of the roads have now been paved. Which means smoother riding, but also a lot more traffic. Manali to Leh is especially very busy. But also very beautiful. We spent 6days cycling Manali to Leh. But I think it would be wiser to slow even more down. Especially the first couple of days, as we were not acclimatized well enough on Barralacha La, the first pass close to 5.000m. And once you get over, you end up in a valley where you cannot get below 4.300m. And a fun fact - every place can be spelled in a handful different ways, which makes navigating interesting. Some places even have 2 different names. So when comparing maps, and talking to locals, it is hard to find the places. But makes the trip all the more fun. And lastly - there are Dhabas and homestays everywhere. From Manali to Leh I wouldnâ€™t carry stove or tent. Even on the whole round trip we did in 4 weeks, we only used the stove twice and the tent 3-4 times. But not because we had to, just because we wanted to. In towns you can easily get some samosas or similar to bring on the bikeâ€¦ Anyways - just wanted to give you some new insights. Hope you do the trip next year. But be prepared for some really high passes ðŸ™‚
data.author: Kenneth Bruun JÃ¸rgensen

data.text: , thank you. Great information! And nice to know we can get away without the stove and the tent. We're expecting the Manali-Leh road to be in pretty good shape but we've read lots of reports about poor road conditions between Shimla and Manali, particularly as the road gets closer to Manali. By starting in Shimla we should have plenty of time to acclimatise to the altitudes before we hit the highest passes. Three years ago in Peru we walked to 4700m without problems....... but there are no guarantees. And, as you know, we're not getting any younger. Interesting that the prices are so expensive now. I hope the hotel for 3700 rupees was pretty special. I'll pick your brains over the coming months for more information.
data.author: Joe Sealby

data.text: , thank you. I have read many parts of your journal and will refer to lots more. You were really fortunate to get through so early the year you rode. NZers, Rhys and Dink, set off several weeks later the year they rode and were blocked, requiring a big backward step and detour.
data.author: Joe Sealby

data.text: Yes, I remember, they too were following our journal. Wonder how they are??
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: great updates, I agree with the slowing down not only for acclimatizing, just enjoying the ride. In lower India, (Kochi to Varanasi) we mailed our stove and kept only the mosquito net and one sleeping bag as a "backup" to shelter if we didn't find any. We had a contact in Rishkesh and picked up the extra great for the Himalayas. Loved the street food, potato vada and samosas!!
data.author: Rachel Hugens

data.text: you are most welcome to get back for more updates. Just 2 things: Shimla to Manali I expect you will be going through Spiti Valley? It is beautiful and less spoiled. The roads are fun. But you know what kind of bikes we ride ðŸ™‚ Just wanted to be sure you are not planning on the direct highway, as on a bycicle itâ€™s not doable due to construction work and heavy traffic. Second. The prices. Actually I lied. Our most expensive stay was 5.500 rupees. 900 is very rare to find. Average pricerange is around 2.500-3.000. Maybe you can negotiate 500 off. 4.700 is high. But there is still quite a way up to 5.300 ðŸ™‚ but you will be fine. You guys are tough so no problem ðŸ‘Š
data.author: Kenneth Bruun JÃ¸rgensen

data.text: , thank you for the information. And, yes, I won't hesitate to contact you with questions when I have some. It is the Spitti Valley we will ride. And, yes, we will only be using our touring bikes but I figure if we take our time we will get there. Riding Manali to Leh in 6 days is insane. We couldn't even contemplate doing it in that time. Being retired, we can take as long as we like and will likely take 10 or 11 days.
data.author: Joe Sealby

data.text: I have contacted them afor information and all seems well. I believe Rhys is considering a ride in Zanskar.
data.author: Joe Sealby

data.text: Just go multifuel. I donâ€™t think anyone in history of mankind has regretted making life so much easier for themselves. Any gas station will have fuel instead of a very limited amount of shops when using gas.
